Astronomers Discover a Mysterious Bar-Shaped Cloud of Iron Within the Iconic Ring Nebula
Humans have been eyeing the colorful Ring Nebula for nearly 250 years, but testing out a new telescope tool led to the perplexing finding
A famous nebula is revealing new secrets even after being observed for almost 250 years.
The Ring Nebulaâ€”a glowing gas cloud that looks like a series of colorful ringsâ€”has a strange bar-shaped clump of iron atoms within it, data from a new telescope instrument suggests. Researchers describe the discovery in a paper published on January 16 in the journal Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.
â€œIt is exciting to see that even a very familiar objectâ€”much studied over many decadesâ€”can throw up a new surprise when observed in a new way,â€ study co-author Roger Wesson, an astronomer at Cardiff University in Wales, tells Reutersâ€™ Will Dunham.
While not visible with the naked eye, the Ring Nebula, also called Messier 57 or NGC 6720, resides about 2,500 light-years from Earth and can be easily spotted within the constellation Lyra with binoculars or a backyard telescope. French astronomer Charles Messier identified the football-shaped gas cloud in 1779.
Fun fact: Discovery mix-up
For hundreds of years, many people credited the French astronomer Antoine Darquier de Pellepoix with the discovery of the Ring Nebula. But scientific sleuths recently figured out that Messier was actually the first person known to document it.
The celestial object formed a few thousand years ago when a dying star expelled its external layers, and the colors come from different chemical elements. In the Hubble Space Telescopeâ€™s images of the Ring Nebula, dark blue represents helium, light blue represents hydrogen and oxygen, and red represents nitrogen and sulfur.
Wesson and his colleagues looked at the famous object in 2023 while testing a new instrument on the William Herschel Telescope in Spain. With the WHT Enhanced Area Velocity Explorer (WEAVE) tool, the researchers could see visible light separated into different wavelengths across the entire face of the nebula. â€œBy obtaining a spectrum continuously across the whole nebula, we can create images of the nebula at any wavelength and determine its chemical composition at any position,â€ Wesson says in a statement.
â€œWhen we processed the data and scrolled through the images, one thing popped out as clear as anythingâ€”this previously unknown â€˜barâ€™ of â€¦ iron atoms in the middle of the familiar and iconic ring,â€ he adds.
The bar is quite long, stretching across a length about 500 times the distance of Plutoâ€™s orbit around the sun, and fitting snugly inside the nebulaâ€™s innermost layer, per the statement. The researchers estimate that the iron atoms have a cumulative mass comparable to that of Mars.
Moreover, itâ€™s â€œweirdâ€ that the iron cloud doesnâ€™t appear to host any of the chemical elements found elsewhere in the nebula, study co-author Janet Drew, an astrophysicist at University College London, tells Reuters.
The research team currently has two hypotheses for how the iron bar arose. It may represent a previously unknown aspect of how a dying star expels its layers, or it might be the remnants of a rocky planet that got vaporized during the layer-shedding process. More work is needed to figure out the barâ€™s origins, and Wesson hopes to find other examples of iron clumps within nebulas, which he doubts is a one-of-a-kind occurrance in the Ring Nebula, per the statement.
â€œWe look forward to getting more data to follow up on this discovery, to try to unravel this new problem and work out where the iron bar has come from,â€ Wesson tells Reuters.

These Are the Top Ten Most Anticipated Museums Opening Around the World in 2026
New institutions dedicated to digital art, exploration, hip-hop, conservation and more are expected to welcome visitors this year
Visitors to the Smithsonian Institution have a lot to look forward to in 2026. The National Air and Space Museum will complete its multiyear renovation with the reopening of its remaining galleries on July 1, the National Museum of African American History and Culture marks its 10th anniversary with a block-party bash in September and the Hirshhornâ€™s revitalized Sculpture Garden reopens in October.
America commemorates its 250th birthday this year, and the Smithsonian museums are sharing in the semiquincentennial celebration with a range of exhibitions, festivities and reopenings. The historic carousel on the National Mall is scheduled to reopen to the public in time for D.C.â€™s Fourth of July anniversary party, and the Smithsonian Castle will pause its first major renovation in more than 50 years to reopen to the public from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day. Along with a visitorâ€™s center, cafÃ© and souvenir shop, the Castle will feature a special exhibition, â€œAmerican Aspirations,â€ showcasing artifacts reflecting America's journey, including abolitionist Harriet Tubman's hymnal. Another exhibition, â€œIn Pursuit of Life, Liberty & Happiness,â€ opens at the National Museum of American History on May 14 and highlights 250 objects that explore the ideals of the Declaration of Independence, such as the desk Thomas Jefferson used to write the Declaration of Independence and the oldest surviving American fighting ship. This year will also see the expansion of the annual Smithsonian Folklife Festival. Titled â€œOf the People: The Smithsonian Festival of Festivals,â€ this larger, multisite experience aims to explore festivals as a powerful tool of civic engagement and cultural exchange.
Around the globe, a range of new museums dedicated to everything from Aboriginal Australian people to hip-hop culture are scheduled to open. The worldâ€™s first museum of A.I. digital arts, Dataland in Los Angeles, is expected to welcome public visitors, as is the United Arab Emirates' Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, an enormous repository of modern and contemporary art. The opening of Londonâ€™s Museum of Shakespeare has been delayed indefinitely, thoughâ€”fingers crossedâ€”it could happen this year.
Whether youâ€™re looking to take on the role of a National Geographic explorer or marvel at a Picasso painting up-close in a converted Art Deco garage, these 10 museums will open new ways to experience, appreciate and understand the world around us.
The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art; Los Angeles
Nearly a decade in the making, the Lucas Museum of Narrative Art is finally set to open in L.A.â€™s Exposition Park on September 22. This brainchild of American filmmaker George Lucas and American businesswoman Mellody Hobson celebrates the universal language of visual storytelling and its ability to connect people. Situated on an 11-acre campus, the five-story, 300,000-square-foot building will feature 35 galleries and a permanent collection of over 40,000 works highlighting all forms of narrative art, including murals, sculpture, photography, posters, illustrations, animation cels and even magic-lantern slides (painted or photographed images on glass plates). Along with images by beloved illustrators like Norman Rockwell and Beatrix Potter, original comic strips by cartoonists such as Charles Schulz and Jack Kirby, and iconic works by painter Frida Kahlo and photographer Dorothea Lange, the museum will also showcase cinematic artifacts, including lightsabers and original costumes from Lucasâ€™ own Star Wars universe. Additional amenities include two on-site theaters, a restaurant and a retail store.
National Geographic Museum of Exploration; Washington, D.C.
Since 1888, the National Geographic Society has illuminated the wonders of our world through travel, science, education and storytelling. This summer, the new National Geographic Museum of Exploration will help bring these wonders to life, using cutting-edge technology, visual journeys and interactive experiences. Located at the Society's headquarters in D.C., the over-100,000-square-foot, sustainably built space will feature a â€œwalking dark rideâ€ that transports visitors to remote fieldwork expeditions and an interactive, large-scale digital installation of National Geographicâ€™s magazine covers, beginning with its first issue in 1888. Visitors will be able to watch National Geographic films and exploration stories in an immersive, 400-seat theater and enjoy a nighttime courtyard experience that recreates six global ecosystems through life-size animal sculptures, touchable prints and audioscapes. Guests enter the museum through an 11-foot-tall yellow border that mimics the magazineâ€™s iconic cover frame.
The museumâ€™s inaugural exhibit, â€œPhoto Ark: Animals of Earth,â€ uses large-scale projections, touch interactives and images from the National Geographic Photo Ark, created and led by National Geographic Explorer Joel Sartore, to inspire protection of the worldâ€™s at-risk species.
UBS Digital Art Museum; Hamburg, Germany
Scheduled to open in the spring, the UBS Digital Art Museum will be Europeâ€™s largest institution dedicated to digital and immersive art. Visitors will be treated to a fully integrated art experience, with approximately 70,000 square feet of exhibition space, soaring 39-foot-high ceilings and a permanent, multisensory work by international digital artist collective teamLab that occupies the entire museum. The exhibit, â€œteamLab Borderless,â€ consists of large-scale projections, interactive environments and everchanging narratives that forgo fixed boundaries and move throughout rooms, responding to each personâ€™s movement, touch and physical presence. The museum is located within Hamburgâ€™s HafenCity district, a massive waterfront development area known for its experimental architecture.
London Museum; London
The former Museum of London closed in December 2022 to reinvent itself as the soon-to-open London Museum. With easy access to public transit and significantly more space (290,000 square feetâ€”roughly 6.6 acresâ€”up from 183,000 square feet), this new iteration is scheduled to open in late 2026 in the cityâ€™s former Smithfield Market district. The London Museum aims to tell the story of Londonersâ€”such as Winifred Herbert, who served as a cook during World War II, and fashion designer Mary Quantâ€”across 450,000 years, and will be one of the largest urban history collections in the world. It holds more than six million objects documenting the cityâ€™s history, including Roman mosaics, medieval armor, Victorian-era ironwork and street artist Banksyâ€™s Piranhas, a painted box that appeared on a central London street in 2024. A unique feature of the new space will be a train line that allows passengers to peek inside the galleries as it passes.
The museumâ€™s permanent galleries will occupy Smithfieldâ€™s abandoned Victorian General Market. The adjacent 1960s Poultry Market, opening in 2028, will house temporary exhibitions, collection stores and a learning center. The area has significant history: Smithfield once served as a Roman cemetery and hosted the boisterous Bartholomew Fair. It also played a prominent role in the novels of Londoner Charles Dickens, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.
MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives; Tokyo
Tokyoâ€™s MoN Takanawa: The Museum of Narratives blends traditional Japanese culture with cutting-edge technology. When it opens in March, this multilevel (six stories above ground, three below), experimental museum will combine traditional arts (like Kabuki) and food with manga, music and science, connecting the past with the future. New themes will be presented twice annually, beginning with the inaugural â€œLife as Culture,â€ which explores how everyday actions such as working, eating and resting create and sustain civilization.
The museum offers a unique mix of Japanese and futuristic aesthetics. Along with a restaurant and cafÃ©, MoN Takanawa also includes an underground theater immersed in digital LED panels and an experiential area for workshops. Thereâ€™s a traditional tatami mat space for relaxing, an on-site library and three open-air terraces, including one where visitors can soak tired feet.
Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope; Arusha, Tanzania
Jane Goodall died in October 2025, but the dreams of the groundbreaking English primatologist and environmental activist live on in Tanzania. Goodall spent her life connecting with the natural world, and Dr. Jane's Dream: The Goodall Centre of Hope inspires visitors to do the same. The space is scheduled to open in late October next to the Arusha Cultural Heritage Center, about 50 miles from Moshi, Mount Kilimanjaroâ€™s gateway town. Brought together by a team of Disney alumni and African artists, Dr. Janeâ€™s Dream will embody the scientistâ€™s message of active hope through interactive exhibits, community-led conservation initiatives and screenings at an on-site theater. Visitors can listen to Goodallâ€™s English translations of chimp cries at a stand-alone kiosk, see elaborately carved and painted tree trunks created by local Makonde artists and even â€œfishâ€ for food in a recreated termite mound using small probes, similar to how chimpanzees did in Goodallâ€™s groundbreaking 1960 discovery.
Larrakia Cultural Centre; Northern Territory, Australia
Aboriginal Australian people have one of the oldest continuous living cultures on the planet. Australiaâ€™s Larrakia Cultural Centre pays homage to the Larrakia peopleâ€” traditional owners of the land and sea that today comprise the countryâ€™s Greater Darwin Region, whose history and stories date back tens of thousands of years. At this multilevel space overlooking Darwin Harbor, visitors will be able to participate in hands-on painting and weaving workshops, observe Aboriginal music performances and learn the Larrakia language. The museum will display plenty of Larrakia treasures in its extensive exhibit space. These include sacred artifacts, such as glass spearheads and personal ornaments, that have been repatriated from international and Australian institutions.
The building features a bird-shaped roof that evokes a Larrakia ancestral being. Inside, there will be a restaurant showcasing local flavors, art studios and a retail shop, while outdoor areas will brim with native landscaping, an amphitheater with a sand performance area, and a saltwater ceremonial pond. Itâ€™s scheduled to open in October.
The Hip Hop Museum; Bronx, New York
The musical genre known as hip-hop came into the world in the 1970s. Known for its stylized rhythmic sounds, turntables and rapping, hip-hop became a cultural movement, influencing everything from fashion to technology. New Yorkâ€™s Hip Hop Museum, opening along the Harlem River waterfront this autumn, celebrates it all.
Situated just a couple of miles south of â€œthe birthplace of hip-hop,â€ 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx, the 55,000-square-foot museum will be home to 30,000 objects highlighting how hip-hop has impacted the world, making its way to concert arenas and influencing dance, politics, education and more.
Floor-to-ceiling displays will include items previously showcased at the museumâ€™s temporary location in the Bronx Terminal Market, such as Dapper Dan custom-made jackets and Rappinâ€™ Max Robot, the first hip-hop comic book. Artist and designer Eric Orr created the four-issue series in 1986 with assistance from pop artist Keith Haring.
Center of Islamic Civilization; Tashkent, Uzbekistan
Although Uzbekistan is officially a secular state, Islam remains a key part of its culture and identity. Opening in March, the Center of Islamic Civilization in Tashkent will highlight the countryâ€™s contributions to Islam and serve as a global hub for studying and promoting the religionâ€™s history, science and spiritual heritage. The three-story structure will feature more than 150,000 square feet of exhibit space and eight galleries showcasing Uzbekistan's Islamic heritage. They will include a collection of 114 Quranic manuscripts created by renowned rulers and calligraphers through the ages and a seventh-century Othman Quran (one of the oldest in the world). The center will also have interactive educational zones that utilize modern tech; for example, a series of â€œliving portraitsâ€ of historical thinkers and scientists will answer visitorsâ€™ questions using artificial intelligence. The institution touts a research center devoted to the study and preservation of Islam, labs for restoring ancient manuscripts and a 460-seat conference hall.
The architecture of the center blends Timurid-era Central Asian traditions (including intricate tilework and a 213-foot-tall blue dome) with modern design, putting Islamâ€™s vast heritage on full display.
The Kanal-Centre Pompidou; Brussels, Belgium
Brussels' first museum dedicated to modern and contemporary art is scheduled to open November 28. The Kanal-Centre Pompidou will be one of Europeâ€™s largest museums, with 430,000 square feet of space. This cultural hub is part of the landmark Centre Pompidou in Paris and emphasizes 21st-century Belgian art along with works from the main museumâ€™s expansive collection. Visitors will be able to study pieces by pioneer of abstract art Wassily Kandinsky and Cubist Pablo Picasso, marvel at video installations such as artist Anthony McCall's light sculptures, and explore one of pop artist Roy Lichtensteinâ€™s porcelain enamel-on-steel prints. Along with both permanent and temporary exhibitions, the museum will feature live music, dance and other performing arts, a library and a bakery. Itâ€™s all housed within Brusselsâ€™ former CitroÃ«n garage, an Art Deco industrial space that has been transformed and repurposed.

Archaeologists Say Theyâ€™ve Detected the Largest Stand-Alone Ancient Roman Villa Ever Unearthed in Wales
The mansionâ€™s foundations and floors are likely well-preserved, according to geophysical surveys. The discovery provides new insights into the Roman occupation in the region
Using ground-penetrating radar, researchers in south Wales have uncovered the foundations of an ancient Roman villa. The discovery illuminates the history of Roman occupation in the region, suggesting that it was more than just a military outpost for the empire.
The villa could be the largest known stand-alone structure of its kind to be found in Wales. It was discovered in Margam Country Park, located in the county of Neath Port Talbot, during geophysical surveys by the local company Terradat. The surveys were commissioned by the ArchaeoMargam project, a collaboration between nearby Swansea Universityâ€™s Center for Heritage Research and Training, Neath Port Talbot Council and Margam Abbey Church.
The project aimed to uncover Margamâ€™s pre-industrial heritageâ€”and according to a statement from Swansea University, â€œthe team struck gold.â€
The massive villaâ€™s foundations, located roughly three feet below the surface, stretch about 141 feet long, Langlands tells BBC Newsâ€™ Steffan Messenger. The â€œreally impressive and prestigiousâ€ structure appears to have six main front rooms and two halls leading to eight rear rooms.
Southeast of the mansion is the footprint of another structure, which may have been a meeting hall or agricultural storage facility. The buildings appear to have been surrounded by a defensive enclosure, which covered an area of more than 25,000 square feet.
â€œAlmost certainly youâ€™ve got a major local dignitary making themselves at home here,â€ Langlands explains to BBC News. â€œThis would have been quite a busy placeâ€”the center of a big agricultural estate and lots of people coming and going.â€
After the Romans invaded Britain in 43 C.E., they built structures such as military forts, roads, walls and baths. In Wales, most Roman ruins were built for the army, like the large Roman fortress and bath complex in nearby Caerleon. Stately Roman homes arenâ€™t commonly found in Wales. However, the newly discovered foundations remind Langlands of sites found in places like Gloucestershire, Somerset and Dorset.
Quick fact: How long did the Romans control Britain?
The emperor Claudius invaded Britain in 43 C.E., and the Romans remained in power until around 410 C.E.
The newly discovered villa could demonstrate that Wales wasnâ€™t just a â€œkind of liminal borderland,â€ Langlands says to the New York Timesâ€™ Stephen Castle. Instead, it may have been â€œjust as Roman as anywhere else weâ€™ve got in the heartlands of the province of Britannia.â€
As the archaeologist explains in the statement, itâ€™s too early to date the Margam villa or determine who built it. However, he tells the Guardian, â€œI think weâ€™re in the fourth centuryâ€”it really fits that kind of late Roman flourish that we see in the southwest of Britain.â€
Because Margam has been a deer park since at least the Middle Ages, it has not been disturbed by agricultural ploughing. As such, researchers are hoping to find the villa to be well-preserved when they eventually excavate it, and the surveys indicate that much of the villaâ€™s flooring and foundations are intact. The team has optimistically nicknamed the site â€œthe Port Talbot Pompeii,â€ in reference to the Roman city that was covered in volcanic ash in 79 C.E.
â€œWherever you get villas like this, theyâ€™re almost certainly surrounded by other edifices of the period,â€ Langlands says in a video from Swansea University. â€œWeâ€™ve probably got trading centers here. We know weâ€™ve got the Roman roads here. There should be a bathhouse somewhere, and almost certainly thereâ€™ll be other small Roman farmsteads.â€
Researchers are keeping the exact location of the buried villa a secret to prevent outsiders from illegally digging on the site before the experts. The team shared its findings with the local community at Margam Abbey Church on January 17.
â€œItâ€™s out of this world,â€ Margaret Jones, a retired teacher from Port Talbot, tells BBC News. â€œIâ€™m still a bit shellshocked at the thought that this place where I played, where my children and grandchildren have playedâ€”that under our feet was this incredible house.â€

A Robot Is Unraveling the Secrets of How Some Bats Bounce Sound Waves Off Leaves to Find Insect Prey
A new study from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute used a robot to mimic common big-eared batsâ€™ echolocation skills
Common big-eared bats are remarkable hunters. In 2019, bat ecologist Inga Geipel and her colleagues reported that the roughly two-inch-long creatures seem to use leaves like â€œacoustic mirrorsâ€ to echolocate silent, motionless insect prey.
â€œThink of shining a light at an oblique angle or a steep angle at the mirror,â€ says Geipel, of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. â€œYou donâ€™t get the light reflected back to you.â€ But it could bounce off another objectâ€”like a dragonfly resting on a leafâ€”which reflects the light back into your face.
â€œThatâ€™s what the bats do,â€ she says.
But how could a bat possibly know the position and orientation of every nearby leaf to situate itself at the best listening spot? New research involving a robot has demonstrated a potential, more efficient foraging technique: As a bat travelsâ€”making rapid clicking sounds along the wayâ€”the leaf angles change relative to the creature, and it can discriminate the weak echo of an empty leaf from the stronger echo of one holding prey.
Geipel and some colleagues involved in the previous study describe their new findings on January 14 in the Journal of Experimental Biology.
Did you know? A big, broad diet
Common big-eared bats eat a wide range of prey, including beetles, caterpillars, spiders and even lizards. They eat relatively large creatures that are sometimes even the same size as the small bats.
Back in 2019, the â€œacoustic mirrorâ€ discovery raised new questions for the researchers. For instance, figuring out the locations and angles of all surrounding leaves would require a lot of the batsâ€™ brain power and energy, Geipel says.
To figure out a simpler and more likely hunting strategy, the team built a robot and had it echolocate a 3D-printed dragonfly positioned on one of five artificial leaves. The machine was programmed to continuously emit ultrasonic callsâ€”too high-pitched for humans to hearâ€”and assess changes in echo strength as it traveled along a nearly ten-foot-long track. Weak or diminishing echoes led the robot to lose interest, while consistently strengthening echoes from different positions caused it to reorient toward the source, indicating potential prey.
When tested in 150 trials with various leaf tilt angles, the robot successfully detected the location of the fake dragonfly 98 percent of the time.
The study suggests that common big-eared bats should be â€œable to perceive the echolocation glints across a really wide range of angles, so they can fly in front of the cluttered background,â€ says Teague Oâ€™Mara, a behavioral ecologist and director of conservation evidence at Bat Conservation International who was not involved in the study.
â€œItâ€™s not so important what angles that the leaves are sitting at. For them, it is that theyâ€™re still going to be able to pick up that really faint echolocation signal coming back to the bats to find that prey,â€ he adds.
Geipel says using a robot to model bat foraging behaviors allows for precise control over various factors, such as sensory inputs and environmental conditions. This helps researchers like her explore how simple echolocation tools could support the sophisticated navigation and prey detection system that bats use.
â€œI think this study gives us a good base to go back to look at the behavior in a more generalized way and see if this could be the underlying strategy for all gleaning bats to find the location of food in a more detailed and precise way,â€ Geipel says.
While more research is needed, she hopes that insights from how bats scan leaves for prey could inspire new agricultural technologies. She envisions robots moving through crop fields to detect and target pest insects, reducing the need for broad pesticide use, and automated systems that identify and harvest ripe fruit.
